Knowing more. Performing worse.

The expertise paradox describes how deep knowledge can sometimes backfire.<[silence:2400]>
It’s like a chef with 20 years of experience overcomplicating a simple dish—while a beginner nails it by following basic steps.<[silence:2400]>

Experts rely on intuition, but that intuition can blind them.<[silence:1200]>
A study of radiologists found that experienced doctors missed obvious tumors when distracted by rare details—novices spotted them faster by sticking to checklists.<[silence:2400]>
Or consider chess masters: they see more possible moves, but under time pressure, they hesitate—while intermediates play decisively.<[silence:2400]>

The paradox isn’t about skill fading.<[silence:1200]>
It’s about expertise creating too many options—like a mechanic diagnosing a car’s noise as 10 possible issues, while the trainee just checks the oil.<[silence:1200]>
Solutions? Simplify.<[silence:1200]>
Use rules of thumb.<[silence:1200]>
Or teach experts to unlearn what they assume they know.<[silence:1200]

Cognitive overload.<[silence:1200]>
The beginner’s advantage.<[silence:1200]>
When rules replace instinct.
